definition: to covet/to long for/to lust after

sentences.english: The end result was tickled constantly coveted position of cui presidents.
sentences.chinese: 这样的结局却乐坏了不断觊觎部长位置的崔社长。

sentences.english: We cannot let North Korea covet even an inch of our territory.
sentences.chinese: 我们不能让朝鲜觊觎我们哪怕是一寸领土。

sentences.english: A jackal watches from a distance, hoping for a few scraps when the lions are done.
sentences.chinese: 远处，一只豺狗暗中注视，觊觎狮子的残羹剩饭。

sentences.english: Clearly, these are benefits coveted by any and all suppliers.
sentences.chinese: 显然，这些无不得益于觊觎的任何及所有的供应商。

sentences.english: He was kept starting for the manager's seat.
sentences.chinese: 他一直觊觎着经理的职位。

sentences.english: A humiliated pretender governed a rump kingdom from Bourges in the south.
sentences.chinese: 造反势力是由觊觎王位者领导的。

sentences.english: But about 10 different clearinghouses are vying for the business.
sentences.chinese: 但是有大约10家不同的结算所都在觊觎这项业务。

sentences.english: You've been on the Love Boat or know someone who has.
sentences.chinese: 你要么已经上了贼船，要么正在觊觎。

sentences.english: The young man pretended to the throne.
For example, they might have the flashy car and big house which you always wanted.
sentences.chinese: 举例来讲，他们或许有那些你时常觊觎名车豪宅。

sentences.english: I am not seeking the leadership, nor acting with anyone else.
sentences.chinese: 我并不觊觎首相职务，也不寻求其他署理职位。

sentences.english: Whenever a man has cast a longing eye on them (offices), a rottenness begins in his conduct.
sentences.chinese: 一旦有人觊觎官职，此人品行则已开始堕落。

sentences.english: This is, in one view, an opportunity that the United States should greedily covet.
sentences.chinese: 从某种角度来说，这应是美国觊觎的机遇。

sentences.english: Mr Appleby does not covet power.
sentences.chinese: 艾波比先生不觊觎权力。

definition: to water at the mouth/to drool
to dip a finger (idiom); fig. to get one's finger in the pie/to get a share of the action/abbr. for 染指於鼎|染指于鼎
to spy upon/to lie in wait for (an opportunity)
to glare like a tiger watching his prey (idiom)/to eye covetously
to peep at/to spy on/to peek
the quick-footed climb up first (idiom)/the early bird catches the worm/first come, first served
to be afraid of the consequences/restraining fear
see 居心叵測|居心叵测[ju1 xin1 po3 ce4]
to begin to stir (idiom)/to get restless/to become threatening
to loot a burning house/to profit from sb's misfortune (idiom)
